Martin Luther King argued in favor of an unconditional basic income for all 
Americans (whether they do any work or not), rather than the paternalistic 
degrading and inefficient means tested programs we have now. He was pretty 
much ok with people choosing to be dependent on a free ride for the 
government if they were content with just getting by, but opposed having 
perverse incentives that would make them fear to loose those benefits if 
they dared aspire to and work for a better standard of living.

He may have been moving towards a Georgist or Geo-Libertarian position late 
in his life. He did quote Henry George quite positively in his last book, 
although he did not appear to fully grasp the importance of abolishing all 
other taxes while shifting to a Land Value Tax. Martin Luther King would 
support the sort of Basic Income proposal that they are working towards in 
Switzerland, rather than the superior Citizens' Dividend system.﻿

+Gene Anthony As always, people being fired for something they said should 
be judged on a case-by-case basis. In this particular case it was 
justified, and here's why: Anthony was in a public figure position, which 
means that the way people viewed him affected how they viewed his 
employers. In other words, when the general public started noticing 
Anthony's bigotry, they immediately started associating said bigotry with 
his show and the radio network it was on. A network cannot afford being 
associated with racism (unless that's their market niche) because that 
means they lose listeners and therefore stock value. In these scenarios 
companies make a careful evaluation of their options (in this case firing 
Anthony or keeping him on air) and choose the one that they deem less 
harmful to their business. SiriusXM decided that firing Anthony was the 
better option for them, so they did just that. It had nothing to do with 
their political views or any ethical considerations.

Shows like O&A and Stern make their money off pandering to the lowest 
common denominator, which is fine as a business model, as it clearly 
works.  I've listened to plenty of both, and while it's not the most 
highbrow entertainment out there, it's fine to listen to in the background.
Problem with needing controversy to run your business model is that 
eventually you go too far, and say what you will about 1st Amendment rights 
and censorship, some things can't be walked back as easily as others, and 
the right to say something doesn't absolve you of the consequences for 
saying it.
O&A and Stern went on Sirius because they couldn't get away with what 
they'd like to do on other channels, and Sirius needed popular 
entertainment to turn people on to their pay per view model, so it was a 
marriage made in heaven for both sides.  But clearly it was a marriage of 
convenience, and Sirius has done the math and figures it's better to lose A 
than keep him on and risk losses from his staying.
That's not censorship, that's the metrics of running a business.

What bothers me about these instances is that no one ever bothers to 
rebuttal against the points made by people with politically incorrect 
views. Gary Oldman, as poorly worded as he put it, did make a cultural 
statement, and no one is addressing that. Instead, he was made to apologize 
insincerely to the people he "wounded", and that's all that ever came out 
of that.

Ant's tweets are just another version of the same cultural statement that 
he's made numerous times on the show, and you know what happens on O&A when 
he says shit like this? People debate him! Jimmy Norton, Bill Burr, Patrice 
O'Neal, etc... have all pitched into the conversation with honest, 
well-thought rebuttals to Anthony's race views without taking the easy 
route like so many outlets, TYT included, by calling him a racist bigot and 
just ending the conversation there. Even if it doesn't change his views, 
millions of people listen to the show. Therein lies the immense value of 
truly uninhibited free speech and expression, and the very antithesis of 
the politically correct mentality.

Sirius has all the right to fire Anthony. It's their business, and they've 
disliked Cumia for years. I'm sure they looked for any excuse to end their 
contract with him. But when people en-masse call and really push for the 
firing of someone for what they say, it sets a bad precedent that no one 
really thinks twice about. You do not get rid of racism by censoring and/or 
disenfranchising racists. All you're doing is ending the dialogue, and 
everyone continues to think what they think.

I also have to point out once again that calling Ant a perv for taking that 
picture is a rather irresponsible assumption of his motives. It serves as a 
baseless attack on his character, and nothing more. Keep it up and you'll 
give O'Reilly a run for his money!﻿
